1.5 Five-Year Accident History

Calpine is required to complete a review of the covered process for incidents occurring in the five-year period prior to the submittal date for the regulation. There were no EPA reportable incidents in the last five year period.

1.6 Emergency Response Programs

Hay Road Energy Center maintains a written emergency response program. The program addresses all aspects of emergency response, including proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, spill response measures, evacuation plans and personnel accounting, notification of emergency response agencies and the public in the event of a release. In the event of an ammonia spill, Hay Road Energy Center may respond will limited defensive actions.

The emergency response program is coordinated with DNREC.

Hay Road Energy Center conducts annual Emergency Response training which may include drills with local emergency responders.

1.7 Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The Hay Road Energy Center constantly strives to improve the safety of the regulated processes by following recommended safe practices, soliciting safety suggestions from employees, conducting hazard analysis studies and investigating process incidents.  The original HAZOP study provided design changes that are being incorporated into the final system design and construction.  Calpine will continue to review and improve the safety of the Anhydrous Ammonia System.

1.4.2 Program 2 Prevention Program

The Hay Road Energy Center has no processes that qualify for the Program 2 Prevention Program.

1.4.3 Chemical-specific Prevention Steps

In addition to the required prevention program elements, Calpine has implemented safety features specific to the hazardous substances used at the Hay Road Power Complex.  The Anhydrous Ammonia System has been designed to only handle Anhydrous Ammonia.  Calpine compared potential use of both Anhydrous and Aqueous Ammonia and determined that Anhydrous Ammonia was more appropriate to minimize the potential for serious incident or off-site impact due to the following:

* decrease in the number of ammonia deliveries to the site; therefore less truck traffic;
* decrease in the number of ammonia delivery truck hook-ups and disconnects which historically has been when the majority of all Ammonia releases occur; 
* decrease in the number of failure points (i.e., valves, pumps, flanges, etc.); and 
* decrease in the likelihood of corrosion to the system due to the nature of Anhydrous Ammonia, use of double wall piping, use of corrosion protection for underground piping.

Topics include the PHAs and operating procedures; as well as access to any support information for the covered processes.

1.4 Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-specific Prevention

Program 3  - essentially the same as OSHA PSM, except that the program also focuses on protecting the public and the environment.  Program 3 requires 12 of the 14 elements of the OSHA PSM regulation, and is the most rigorous prevention program. It has been established for the Anhydrous Ammonia System.  The following sections briefly describe the elements of Calpine's prevention program that address the EPA RMP rule prevention program requirements.

In addition to the physical parameters that characterize a release, meteorological data are needed by the model to characterize the ambient release conditions.  Meteorological data are used in dispersion models to calculate the distance that the pollutant plume moves downwind and the concentration of the pollutant at any given time or distance.  The meteorological variables that affect the dispersion of a chemical release are as follows:

* Wind Speed and Direction: The wind speed is used to determine the plume dilution, plume transport, plume rise, evaporation rate, and magnitude of the concentration.  Wind direction defines the direction in which the plume travels.
* Temperature:  Temperature is used to calculate plume rise and evaporation rates.
* Atmospheric Pressure: is used to calculate gas and liquid release rates.
* Atmospheric Stability: Stability is an indication of atmospheric turbulence.  The turbulence is depended upon thermal (heating of the ground) and mechanical (surface roughness and wind speed) effects.  Turbulence also acts to dilute the plume and reduce down wind concentrations.

1.1 Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Calpine is committed to the safety of workers and the public, and the preservation of the environment, through the prevention of accidental releases of hazardous substances.  Calpine implements reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of hazardous substances.  These controls include training programs for personnel; programs to help ensure safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of processes at Calpine; and programs to evaluate the hazards at Calpine.

In order to effectively implement these policies, Calpine established a management system headed by the Power Complex's EHS Specialist to oversee safety-related activities.


1.2 Calpine and Regulated Substances

The Hay Road Energy Center is a power generation facility designed to supply power during high electrical demand periods.  In order to support these operations, Calpine handles regulated substances (Anhydrous Ammonia) in sufficient quantities to be covered by the RMP rule, as shown below.

Although the risk management program at Calpine helps provide assurance that the facility is maintained and operated in a safe manner, it is only one component of the safety program at Calpine.  In fact, Calpine has a comprehensive safety program in place establishing various levels of safeguards against release of a hazardous substance and injuries/damage from a release of a hazardous substance.

Calpine limits the use of hazardous substances.  Before using a hazardous substance at Calpine, less hazardous alternatives are considered. Part of Calpine's RMP compliance philosophy has been the reduction of the use of hazardous substances covered under this regulation. When a hazardous substance is used, Calpine considers the potential for this substance to adversely affect Calpine workers, the public, and the environment and takes steps to prevent any such effects.

Calpine works to prevent releases of the hazardous substances used at the facility.  When a hazardous substance is used at Calpine, the equipment is designed, built, operated, and maintained to reduce the likelihood of an accidental release.  Industry and government standards are adhered to in the design, construction, operation, and maintenance of the equipment.

Calpine limits damage from a release, if such a release were to occur.  Calpine trains workers to react quickly in the event of an accidental release, reducing the consequences of a release were to occur.  In addition, Calpine works with the local fire department and with the local emergency planning committee (LEPC) to help ensure that injuries and/or environmental damage will be minimized if a release does occur.  Calpine has installed devices (monitors, deluge system, dike) to minimize any impact in the unlikely event of a release.

RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN - 5 YEAR RE-SUBMITTAL - 5/3/2022
CALPINE HAY ROAD POWER COMPLEX
WILMINGTON, NEW CASTLE COUNTY, DELAWARE

1. Executive Summary 

Calpine is committed to operating in a manner that is safe for their workers, the public, and the environment. As a demonstration of that commitment, Calpine has developed and implemented Environmental and Workplace Health and Safety Policies to serve as guiding principles for all its employees and operations.  Calpine believes that following these policies is the responsibility of every employee. 

As part of this commitment, Calpine has established a system to help ensure safe operation of the processes at this facility.  One component of this system is a Risk Management Program (RMP) that helps manage the risks at Calpine and that complies with the requirements of the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA's) regulation 40 CFR part 68, Accidental Release Prevention Requirements: Risk Management Programs (the RMP rule) and Delaware's Accidental Release Prevention Regulation.  One of the requirements of the RMP rule is to submit a risk management plan (RMP Plan) describing the risk management program at Calpine.  This document is intended to satisfy the RMP Plan requirement of the RMP rule and to provide the public with a description of the risk management program at Calpine.

The risk management program at Calpine consists of three elements:

1. A hazard assessment to help understand the potential offsite consequences of hypothetical accidental releases and a history of accidents that have occurred during the last five years associated with the use of substances regulated by the RMP rule (regulated substances) - see topics 1.3 and 1.5
2. A prevention program to help maintain and safely operate the processes containing more than a threshold quantity of a regulated substance (covered processes) - see topic 1.4
3. An emergency response program to help respond to accidental releases of regulated substances
